additionalTextInformation.text:
A portrait of Melanchthon in the Stadtgeschichtliches Museum Leipzig, created in 1579, is stylistically very similar to the present painting. A portrait of Martin Luther serves as a pendant to the painting in Leipzig and the same may be asumed of this painting. The pendant could be the painting 'Martin Luther depicted with hands', which also entered the Dresden Kunstkammer in 1621 from the estate of Giovanni M. Nosseni (Inventory 1858, No. 405; Auction Catalogue 1860, No. 78).
[Exhib. Cat. Dresden 2006, 537]
This painting is slightly larger in format (85 x 63.7 cm) in comparison with the portrait of Melanchthon, but the truncated hands and date suggest that the portrait of Melanchthon may have been cropped.
[Herrschaft, cda 2013]

pageContext.description:
Philipp Melanchthon is depicted as a half-length figure facing left. He looks in this direction. He holds as book in both hands. He wears a fur-trimmed cloak.   
The background is light and a shadow is indicatd on the right side of the painting.
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 
63.7 x 47.2 cm
[Exhib. Cat. Dresden 2006, 538]

metadata.title: Portrait of Philipp Melanchthon

pageContext.provenance:
- 1621 entered the Dresden Kunstkammer from the estate of the court architect Giovanni Maria Nosseni
- Inventory 1858, No. 137
- catalogue works for auction 1860, No. 77
- whereabouts unknown 
[Exhib. Cat. Dresden 2006, 538]
- auctione for 14 taler on the 16th of April 1860 
[Exhib. Cat. Dresden 2006, 569]
- the painting was part of the original collection, purchased in Europe in 1869-71 by E. B. Crocker
[Crocker Art Museum, revised 2013]

restorationSurveys.remarks:
Conservation performed by Charles Muskavitch, completed in 1951; seal removed (?), as in 1937, before conservation, there was a seal on the back
[Crocker Art Museum, revised 2013]
